title: Drawing, Design for Allegory of Divine Wisdom, Reception Room, Palazzo Barberini, Rome, 1629–33
title_raw: Design for Allegory of Divine Wisdom, Reception Room, Palazzo Barberini, Rome
medium: Point of brush and brown wash, pen and brown ink, red, black chalk, white chalk on off-white on pinkish laid paper
inscribed: Inscribed with point of brush and brown wash, center right: candidezza; inscribed in pen and brown ink, upper left: 277.
creditline: Museum purchase through gift of various donors
description: Design for a ceiling painting. In the center, one figure sits raised above a group of other figures, who all appear to be focused on the raised figure. At left, two female forms. Top left, putti suggested.
gallery_text: Broad swathes of brown wash block out the figures in this preliminary study for a ceiling in the Palazzo Barberini, Rome. Loose lines of ink deliniate the gestures and contours of Divine Wisdom and her eleven maidens, each personifying various qualities of wisdom. The design’s dense allegorical subtext was intended to glorify the Barberini family. The free exploration evident in this drawing suggest it was among the first of many preparatory drawings for the fresco. Several compositional changes would occur between this and the final work. However, it is the only known drawing connected with the project. The circle behind Divine Wisdom’s head represents the blinding light of the sun. The sweeping curve at the lower half of the page indicates the earth. In the final fresco, an enormous globe would dominate the composition. The inclusion of these two heavenly bodies can be understood as a response to Galileo’s recently published – and challenged- theories of heliocentricity. The design dispenses with all architectural framing devices normally found in illusionistic ceiling frescos. Situated in the large antechamber to the family’s private chapel, viewers are intended to contemplate the scene before entering the chapel, where they could pray for divine wisdom and guidance.
